Authors:
Adama Faye, Jean-Christophe Pintaud, William John Baker,
Bonaventure Sonk√©, Thomas LP Couvreur
Title:
A plastid phylogeny of the African rattans
(Ancistrophyllinae, Arecaceae)
Keywords:
Arecaceae, rattans of Africa, tropical rain forest,
molecular phylogeny
Abstract:
Over one third of African palms are rattans (22 species)
21 of them belonging to the subtribe Ancistrophyllinae (Calamoideae).
African rattans are typically restricted to the tropical rainforests
(TRF) of Central and West Africa and play an important role in the local
forest economy thanks to their use in furniture making. Intergeneric
phylogenetic relationships remain unknown and have never been addressed
using molecular sequence data. We present a first plastid molecular
phylogeny of the subtribe represented by three genera (Eremospatha,
Laccosperma and Oncocalamus). Four chloroplastic intergenic spacers
(psbA-trnH, psbZ-trnFM, atpI-atpH and rps3-rpl16) were sequenced for 80%
of the species found in the subtribe. The data was analyzed using
Maximum Parsimony, Maximum Likelihood and Bayesian Inference methods.
Our results show that the subtribe of Ancistrophyllinae is monophyletic
as well as the three genera. However relationships between genera remain
unresolved. Our analyses provided some details on relationships between
species within Eremospatha and Laccosperma, but not in Oncocalamus. The
species Eremospatha cabrae and Eremospatha dransfieldii were recovered
with strong support as sister and together formed a highly divergent
clade sister to the rest of the genus. The four plastid markers used
here provide interesting levels of resolutions and should be considered
in other species level analyses in palms.
